title: Quiz 4: Facilitative Supervision
description: Test your knowledge on the principles, tasks, and qualities of effective facilitative supervision compared to traditional methods.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of **Traditional Supervision**?
questions.explanation: Traditional supervision is often criticized for being punitive, critical, and focused on individuals rather than systems.
questions.hint: It is the 'old' style that people often fear.

questions.question: Match the Function of Supervision to its description:

pairs.right: Welfare and emotional support of the supervisee

questions.hint: Normative relates to norms/standards; Formative relates to forming skills.

questions.question: What are the qualities of a good **Facilitative Supervisor**? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Facilitative supervisors are listeners, resourceful, respectful mentors, not just fault-finders.
questions.hint: Think about a supervisor you would *want* to have.

questions.question: Facilitative supervision emphasizes 'empowerment' over 'control'.
questions.explanation: Facilitative supervision is about building confidence, self-esteem, and empowering workers.
questions.hint: Does it want the worker to succeed or just obey?

questions.question: The literal meaning of supervision is '___BLANK___' or to inspect the work of others.
A supervisor is planning a visit. Order these supervision activities logically:

items.text: Observing and collecting data on site

questions.explanation: Plan -> Review Background -> Observe -> Discuss/Feedback -> Report.
questions.hint: You prepare first, then do, then report.

questions.question: Which principle of supervision states: 'Lesser the weight of supervision, higher the output'?
questions.explanation: Right intensity implies optimum supervisionâ€”not too much, not too little.
questions.hint: It refers to the amount or 'intensity' of supervision.

questions.question: Which task of supervision involves helping staff identify and solve problems using an **in-service training** approach?
questions.explanation: The Teaching (or Educative) task involves filling knowledge gaps and training staff during supervision.

questions.question: Review the scenario: 'A supervisor visits a facility, finds records incomplete, and immediately shouts at the nurse in front of patients.' What type of supervision is this?
questions.explanation: This behavior (public criticism, focus on fault) is characteristic of Traditional/Punitive supervision.

questions.question: What are the goals of Facilitative Supervision? (Select all that apply)

options.text: To learn what is going on
To improve knowledge, skills, and abilities
To catch people doing things wrong
To enforce strict compliance through fear

questions.explanation: Facilitative supervision aims to learn and improve, not to catch faults or instill fear.
